that title is kenny chesney for all ya'll who dont know.) ok then, i have been meaning to do this update for over two weeks. been putting it off cause they arent pleasant memories, but they are memories nonetheless. also, this is going to be an involved post so sorry if its long. here goes.

the first thing i want to say is that its amazing how tragedy can effect your life. its amazing how people respond and how people can be pulled together in just an instant. there are things that happened the week after my cousins death that i never will forget. my familys reaction and how they pulled together simply because "thats just what we do" was incredible. i cant say that it was amazing, b/c that would counteract the point, but it was comforting. the most important thing that i learned is that your family is your family FOREVER. they love you FOREVER. they are unchanging, unmoving. and no matter how far you run away from them, they are there. and they will always be there...and its that simple.

my sister called me on monday july 3rd at like 6:30 am balling her eyes out. the previous day, we had just been informed in the middle of church service that our associate pastor, one we were both close to, had been killed in an accident. i thought that it had something to do with that. i was half asleep when she told me "jeremy's been killed in iraq" I didnt sleep for days after that. My cousin Jeremy who i grew up with...i was just shocked. the next week i had already planned as my vacation from work, so i decided to take that whole week to spend at my gma's house helping her with stuff that needed to be done for the funeral and so on. i wasnt prepared for the drama there at all. tv crews, newspaper reporters, army people...there everyday. it was a mess. those people had everyone in an emotional mess.
the wake and the funeral...there are some people that you just expect to be emotional. like my sister calling me at 6:30 am. yeah i could handle that from her, cause she's an emotional person. to say the least. when i was at the wake, i counted on my mom's sister angie (who is actually my age and more like my sister, long story) anyways, we were out in the parking lot for the longest time with her trying to get me to go into the building. she finally talked me into going with her to look at the casket. as long as she was going with me i was good. so we walk into the funeral home, get outside the door of the room he was in, and she starts having a breakdown. so then I had to be the one to get her calmed down and into the room. it was me and my aunt (who had just lost her son) that got her to finally calm down. my aunt marched right up to her, looked her straight in the eyes, and said, "Listen to me, suck it up, and get yourself in there and say goodbye. We have to get through this." i'm saying all this one because i will never forget it but also just to prove the point that its amazing how people react in tragedy. its forever set a standard in my mind. 
that week was one of the hardest i've ever had to get through. fourtantely, there good and bad in every situation. so heres some of the good (i guess)
i have not been back "home" (i call it cause thats where i grew up) since andy left me. my roots are in that place, and thats just one thing that i could not bring myself to face for the longest time. what i realize now is that when i was with andy i became a person that HE made me, something he wanted me to be. it was totally not me. and when he left, the person that he made me and the person i convinced myself i was totally shattered. i didnt want to face that reality. i didnt want to go back home and face that i was going to have to rebuild myself again. but i was forced to do it. and look what i realized! spending that week i learned so many things..one of them is remembering who i am. somewhere in between chasing baby drew through the yard with no shoes on (cause you know they dont wear shoes in wv), pushing my cousin's four wheeler out of the mud, taking a call at midnight when i am at the house by myself that the COWS are out of the fence (im scared of cows btw), or taking a "hay ride" with 21 city people from NEW JERSEY up to the cow field, anyways in between this all, i just started laughing hysterically to myself. what a way to have to figure out who you are! good lord above, no wonder i am insane. 

anyways, i hope those two stories connected. all i'm trying to say is because of the situation i was forced to reevaluate some things. and as tough as it was, i have such a greater peace about who I am now. in the midst of such a horrible mess, thank God for small blessings.

<lj-cut text="EVEN THE BEST FALL DOWN SOMETIMES">Family, friends, fellow soldiers mourn Sgt. Brown killed in Iraq 
By Amelia A. Pridemore/Register-Herald Reporter

 
A full military Honor Guard procession carries the casket of U.S. Army Staff Sgt. Jeremy Brown, who died in Mosul, Iraq, after a Humvee rollover, to graveside during his funeral Friday at Blue Ridge Memorial Gardens. (C.L. Garvin/The Register-Herald)  
 
  



 
 
Even though it was soaked with rain, the American flag at half staff still flew at Blue Ridge Funeral Home.

And even though eyes of the people inside were soaked with tears, they still stood to honor a soldier, comrade, husband, father and hero.

U.S. Army Staff Sgt. Jeremy Alexander Brown, 26, of Mabscott, died July 3 in Mosul, Iraq, after a Humvee rollover. He was assigned to the 66th Military Intelligence Company of the 3rd Armored Calvary, and he had served in the Army since 1996. His funeral was conducted at Blue Ridge Funeral Home Friday afternoon, and he was buried at Blue Ridge Memorial Gardens.

Brown was the son of Teresa Lynn Scott Brown and the late John Alexander "Skeet" Brown, who died just five years ago of cancer. His father was exposed to Agent Orange while serving in the Vietnam War. He had two brothers, Jason, his twin, and Greg. Brown graduated from Woodrow Wilson High School in 1997.

He and his wife Rosemary, of West Orange, N.J., married about three years ago after they met while they were both serving in the Army in Korea. He was also the father of a 3 1/2-year-old son, Seth Alexander Brown, of Winchester, Ohio.

Upon entering the funeral home, visitors were able to see a collage of photos from Brown's life - his wedding day and a photo of taking Seth to a petting zoo were included.

Maj. Gen. John F. Kimmons of the U.S. Army Intelligence and Security Command, along with other comrades, was on hand to stand for Brown, a fellow intelligence soldier. Kimmons' son has done two tours of Iraq and one of Afghanistan. Brown was on his second tour of Iraq when he died.

Kimmons highly complimented the work of young soldiers like Brown, and ones enlisting after Sept. 11, 2001, when they knew they would be serving in wartime.

"They have chosen to march to the sound of a gun," he said. "What I have seen really reflects the talent, patriotism and leadership of these youngsters. They are in the harshest of environments in Iraq, and after they get back from a trip over there, they're as high as a kite. They do fantastic stuff there, and the morale is good, even though they're often in danger.

"It's a privilege and an honor to serve with them."

As mourners entered the chapel, fellow soldiers stood by at the doorway. One of these men, trained to fight, struggled to hold back tears. During the service, Army representatives presented Brown's family with a Bronze Star and the Army Commendation Medal.

"The military doesn't give Christmas bonuses, it just gives small pieces of ribbon - but these are pieces of the heart," Kimmons said. "This is for Rosemary, Seth and Mrs. Brown, his family... but we represent Jeremy's other family, the Army family. Even though it's a big place, it's tightly knit. He was a superb intelligence leader in one of our finest, proudest units."

Army representatives read statements from his fellow soldiers. They described a man who took care of his comrades, and always set high standards for them to follow, never allowing them to give up at anything. They also described a man with a good sense of humor, who always took the time to have general conversation with them.

Even when he was fatally injured, they told, he only asked about the status of his fellow soldiers.

"To Jeremy Brown, to his family, to his fellow soldiers, to all soldiers of all ranks in the whole nation, thank you for a job well done," Kimmons said. "God bless Jeremy Brown, God bless his family and God bless America."

Representatives from Gov. Joe Manchin's office attended, reading an executive order declaring that all flags at state offices be flown at half staff on Friday, the day Brown was buried.

Pastor Bobby Meadows remembered more than a solider. He remembered a 6-year-old boy making the decision to be baptized. When he was baptized at Tildon Community Church that day, Jeremy was held up so others could see him because he was so short at the time.

Meadows taught Brown's youth class at church for eight years - and was also Midway native U.S. Navy Petty Officer 1st Class Jeff Taylor's principal at Independence High School for three years. Taylor, a 30-year-old Navy SEAL, died June 28 in eastern Afghanistan when a helicopter he was riding in crashed into a mountain ravine. It was apparently hit by a Taliban rocket-propelled grenade. His memorial service was held Sunday.

"There's no finer young people and no finer families," he said of both the Browns and Taylors.

As the mourners poured out of the funeral home, ready to drive to the cemetery, the rain had stopped. The sun shone brightly for a while as cars filed into the cemetery, where the roads were lined with American flags.

Brown's casket, draped with an American flag, was transported by a U.S. Army Military Honor Guard. As it was moved into and from the hearse that took Brown to his final resting place, soldiers slowly saluted.

Brown's gravesite was located near several others who had served in the military - and directly to the right of his father's.

After performing his graveside rites, his honor guard methodically folded the flag that had draped his casket, making sure every last fold and crease were perfect. His Army Solider Escort described, with each fold, the significance of each. This flag was presented to his wife, and another was presented to his mother.

During the service's final prayer, the wind kicked up a notch. A dove, when released from a basket, flew right beside Brown's casket and his family gathered alongside.

Then as mourners gradually left the gravesite for their cars, Brown's son Seth stood beside his father's casket, waving an American flag as high as his tiny arm could reach.

Sgt. Jeremy A. Brown  
 
  



 
 
Jeremy Brown remembered for dedication to son, service

By Amelia A. Pridemore/REGISTER-HERALD REPORTER

While she watched her grandson play, Teresa Brown remembered how his father would sacrifice anything for his son - and for the soldiers with whom he served.

U.S. Army Staff Sgt. Jeremy A. Brown, 26, of Mabscott, died Sunday when a Humvee rolled over in Mosul, Iraq, Army representatives confirmed. Brown was assigned to the 66th Military Intelligence Company of the 3rd Armored Calvary.

"He said, 'Mom, I have a job to do. ... My men are only 18- and 19-year-old boys, and I have to go over and protect them. I know that I have to go for my men'," his mother recalled when he was preparing in February to return for a second tour in Iraq.

"I told him, 'I understand. We'll be waiting for you when you get home.'"

Losing Jeremy has been especially hard on the family, his brother Jason said, because their father died just five years ago.

John Alexander Brown, was exposed to Agent Orange during Vietnam, and died of cancer.

Jeremy and his wife Rosemary married about three years ago. They met when they were both serving in the Army in Korea. Jeremy also has a 31/2-year-old son, Seth, and another brother, Greg, 21.

Jason, also 26, is his twin.

"He's only been in the world about four minutes less than I have," he said. "It's been pretty rough."

Jeremy was a 1997 graduate of Woodrow Wilson High School who entered the Army right after graduation. While they were growing up, Jason said he and Jeremy hung out in different crowds most of the time, but after he joined the military, they spent more quality time together when Jeremy came home on leave.

They especially loved target practice and riding four-wheelers.

"We're both very stubborn," Jason joked. "We don't give in to peer pressure. We both have very strong character, and we never were easily influenced."

Teresa said her son really grew up after joining the Army. His father told him he would be aching to come home after time in basic training. Even though he realized his father was right, after the basic training, Jeremy found his calling.

"He said, 'I'm good at what I do, I enjoy this, and this is my job.'"

However, Jason said Jeremy grew up even more considerably when he became a father.

"Everything in the world stopped when it came to [Seth]."

Teresa said her favorite memory of her son is when he laid eyes on his son for the first time. Shortly after Seth was born, Seth's mother was becoming depressed because Jeremy was not around. Little did she know, Jeremy was on his way.

"You could just see that awe in his face when he saw his son," she said. "... That's the standout of all."
